title.value: An 8-channel Tx dipole and 20-channel Rx loop coil array for MRI of the cervical spinal cord at 7 Tesla
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the paper and in the citation at the end.
title.quote: An 8-channel Tx dipole and 20-channel Rx loop coil array for MRI of the cervical spinal cord at 7 Tesla

extractions.description: This research paper presents the design, testing, and validation of a parallel transmission/receive coil array for MRI of the human neck and cervical/upper thoracic spinal cord at 7 Tesla. The coil array, consisting of eight transmit dipoles and twenty receive loops, aims to improve the quality of MRI scans by enhancing B1 uniformity and signal-to-noise ratio. The study demonstrates the coil's effectiveness compared to existing solutions.

type.justification: The paper involves practical experiments, construction, and validation of an MRI coil, indicating it is an empirical study.
type.quote: This work presents the design, testing, and validation of a pTx/Rx coil for the human neck and cervical/upper thoracic spinal cord.

name.justification: The focus of the research is on improving MRI technology for spinal cord imaging, which falls under the field of Medical Imaging.
name.quote: Clinical and research magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies of the cervical spinal cord can benefit significantly from the increased signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and contrasts resulting from the recent developments in ultrahigh fields.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses magnetic resonance imaging technology and its development for spinal cord imaging.
name.quote: The quality of cervical spinal cord images can be improved by the use of tailored radiofrequency (RF) coil solutions for ultrahigh field imaging.

name.justification: The paper specifically discusses the design of a transmit/receive coil for MRI, which is a core model in this study.
name.quote: This work presents the design, testing, and validation of a pTx/Rx coil for the human neck and cervical/upper thoracic spinal cord.

is_contributed.justification: The transmit/receive coil configuration is the main contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: This work presents the design, testing, and validation of a pTx/Rx coil for the human neck and cervical/upper thoracic spinal cord.

is_executed.justification: The coil model was validated by simulations, on the workbench, and in the scanner, indicating it was executed.
is_executed.quote: The coil was validated by simulations, on the workbench and in the scanner, with multiple subjects of variable morphologies.

is_compared.justification: The new coil was compared with two state-of-the-art head and head/neck coils, which confirms its comparative evaluation.
is_compared.quote: We compared the proposed coil with two state-of-the-art head and head/neck coils, confirming its superiority in the cervical and upper thoracic regions of the spinal cord.

referenced_paper_title.value: An 8-channel Tx dipole and 20-channel Rx loop coil array for MRI of the cervical spinal cord at 7 Tesla
referenced_paper_title.justification: The model is introduced and described within the same paper, so it shares the paper's title.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This work presents the design, testing, and validation of a pTx/Rx coil for the human neck and cervical/upper thoracic spinal cord.

name.justification: This model was used as a reference in the design of the coil, thus qualifying as a dataset.
name.quote: We used a computer-aided design tool (Autodesk, AutoCAD, version 2018, San Francisco, CA, USA) to design a close-fitting inner coil former. As a reference for this process, we utilized a three-dimensional (3D) average head model created by a procedure described in an earlier work.

referenced_paper_title.value: Integrated AC/DC coil and dipole Tx array for 7T MRI of the spinal cord
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper describes the procedure for creating the 3D model used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: As a reference for this process, we utilized a three-dimensional (3D) average head model created by a procedure described in an earlier work.
